DataElement.preferredName: Person Non Carcinoid Lung Carcinoma Diagnosis Yes No Indicator
DataElement.preferredDefinition: Text term to signify whether a person has a diagnosis of non-carcinoid lung carcinoma.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Person Non Carcinoid Lung Carcinoma Diagnosis
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: A single human being._Negation._A slow growing neuroendocrine tumor, composed of uniform, round, or polygonal cells having monotonous, centrally located nuclei and small nucleoli, infrequent mitoses, and no necrosis.  The tumor may show a variety of patterns, such as solid, trabecular, and acinar.  Electron microscopy shows small secretory granules.  Immunohistochemical studies reveal NSE, as well as chromogranin immunoreactivity.  Malignant histology (cellular pleomorphism, hyperchromatic nuclei, prominent nucleoli, necrosis, and mitoses) can occasionally be seen.  Such cases may have an aggressive clinical course.  Gastrointestinal tract and lung are common sites of involvement._A carcinoma originating in the lung. Lung carcinomas usually arise from the epithelium that lines the bronchial tree (bronchogenic carcinomas), and are classified as small cell or non-small cell carcinomas. Non-small cell lung carcinomas are usually adenocarcinomas, squamous cell carcinomas, or large cell carcinomas. Metastatic carcinomas to the lung are also common, and can be difficult to distinguish from primary tumors.

ObjectClass.preferredName: Person Negation Lung Carcinoma Carcinoid Tumor
ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: A human being.:An operation in which a term denies or inverts the meaning of another term or construction.:A carcinoma originating in the lung. Lung carcinomas usually arise from the epithelium that lines the bronchial tree (bronchogenic carcinomas), and are classified as small cell or non-small cell carcinomas. Non-small cell lung carcinomas are usually adenocarcinomas, squamous cell carcinomas, or large cell carcinomas. Metastatic carcinomas to the lung are also common, and can be difficult to distinguish from primary tumors.:A slow growing neuroendocrine tumor, composed of uniform, round, or polygonal cells having monotonous, centrally located nuclei and small nucleoli, infrequent mitoses, and no necrosis.  The tumor may show a variety of patterns, such as solid, trabecular, and acinar.  Electron microscopy shows small secretory granules.  Immunohistochemical studies reveal NSE, as well as chromogranin immunoreactivity.  Malignant histology (cellular pleomorphism, hyperchromatic nuclei, prominent nucleoli, necrosis, and mitoses) can occasionally be seen.  Such cases may have an aggressive clinical course.  Gastrointestinal tract and lung are common sites of involvement.

Concepts.definition: An operation in which a term denies or inverts the meaning of another term or construction.

A carcinoma originating in the lung. Lung carcinomas usually arise from the epithelium that lines the bronchial tree (bronchogenic carcinomas), and are classified as small cell or non-small cell carcinomas. Non-small cell lung carcinomas are usually adenocarcinomas, squamous cell carcinomas, or large cell carcinomas. Metastatic carcinomas to the lung are also common, and can be difficult to distinguish from primary tumors.

A slow growing neuroendocrine tumor, composed of uniform, round, or polygonal cells having monotonous, centrally located nuclei and small nucleoli, infrequent mitoses, and no necrosis.  The tumor may show a variety of patterns, such as solid, trabecular, and acinar.  Electron microscopy shows small secretory granules.  Immunohistochemical studies reveal NSE, as well as chromogranin immunoreactivity.  Malignant histology (cellular pleomorphism, hyperchromatic nuclei, prominent nucleoli, necrosis, and mitoses) can occasionally be seen.  Such cases may have an aggressive clinical course.  Gastrointestinal tract and lung are common sites of involvement.

Property.preferredDefinition: The process of identifying a disease by the signs and symptoms.

Concepts.definition: The investigation, analysis and recognition of the presence and nature of disease, condition, or injury from expressed signs and symptoms; also, the scientific determination of any kind; the concise results of such an investigation.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: the process of identifying a disease by the signs and symptoms (NCI Glossary).

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: The preferred Value Domain to indicate a question with permissible values of yes/no.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The non-affirmative response to a question.

Concepts.definition: The non-affirmative response to a question.

ValueMeaning.administrativeNotes: 2022.12.28 Alt VM added per ticket request CADSR0001837. aj

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The affirmative response to a question.

Concepts.definition: The affirmative response to a question.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: Conceptual domain that includes value meanings to be used for Indicator Value Meanings such as Yes, No, Unknown, No Applicable

RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: A caDSR representation term that is used to indicate a question with permissible values of yes/no

Concepts.definition: A response or indicator that can have a value of either yes or no.
